fields.abstract: The International Wealth Index (IWI) for Nepal in 2006. The IWI is an internationally standardized wealth index which calculates wealth in terms of assets based on household surveys. This model extrapolated survey results in Nepal to non-surveyed areas based on phone records and top-up patterns, night lights, census data and other factors which were shown to have a proven relationship to observed household charactersitics in the available survey data. The standard deviation is calculated for this index and the interdecile range (a measure of uncertainty).
fields.source: Basco, Garavito, Rigo, Tatem , Pezzulo, Wood, Chamberlain, and Bird (2018) "Geostatistical Tools to Map the Interaction between Development Aid and Indices of Need"

fields.abstract:
The International Wealth Index (IWI) for Nepal in 2006. The IWI is an internationally standardized wealth index which calculates wealth in terms of assets based on household surveys. This model extrapolated survey results in Nepal to non-surveyed areas based on phone records and top-up patterns, night lights, census data and other factors which were shown to have a proven relationship to observed household charactersitics in the available survey data.

The sum is calculated for this index and the interdecile range (a measure of uncertainty).
fields.source: Basco, Garavito, Rigo, Tatem , Pezzulo, Wood, Chamberlain, and Bird (2018) "Geostatistical Tools to Map the Interaction between Development Aid and Indices of Need"

fields.abstract:
The International Wealth Index (IWI) for Nepal in 2006. The IWI is an internationally standardized wealth index which calculates wealth in terms of assets based on household surveys. This model extrapolated survey results in Nepal to non-surveyed areas based on phone records and top-up patterns, night lights, census data and other factors which were shown to have a proven relationship to observed household charactersitics in the available survey data.

The sum, mean and standard deviation is calculated for this index and the interdecile range (a measure of uncertainty).



All spatial data created by Claudio Bosco of the WorldPop project. Full documentation available at: http://docs.aiddata.org/ad4/pdfs/wps49_Geostatistical_Tools_to_Map_the_Interaction_between_Development_Aid_and_Indices_of_Need--optimized.pdf
fields.source: Basco, Garavito, Rigo, Tatem , Pezzulo, Wood, Chamberlain, and Bird (2018) "Geostatistical Tools to Map the Interaction between Development Aid and Indices of Need"

fields.abstract: This dataset shows the estimated population total for each municipality for 2015. All numbers, including past and present numbers, are estimations. These estimations are created through a mix of census data, population growth projections, mobile phone call records, remotely sensed (satellite) data, and inputs from the UN Population Division.
fields.source: The WorldPop program (www.worldpop.org) at the University of Southampton

fields.abstract: This dataset shows the estimated population total for each municipality for 2020. All numbers, including past and present numbers, are estimations. These estimations are created through a mix of census data, population growth projections, mobile phone call records, remotely sensed (satellite) data, and inputs from the UN Population Division.
fields.source: The WorldPop program (www.worldpop.org) at the University of Southampton

fields.abstract: This dataset shows the estimated population variance for each municipality for 2020. All numbers, including past and present numbers, are estimations. These estimations are created through a mix of census data, population growth projections, mobile phone call records, remotely sensed (satellite) data, and inputs from the UN Population Division.
fields.source: The WorldPop program (www.worldpop.org) at the University of Southampton

fields.abstract: The total length of all recognized roads in a municipality. Please note that some DRCN "roads" are actually jeep tracks or even pathways, particularly in the Far West, and should be understood as such. The dataset does not include small village paths or roads constructed since this time.
fields.source: Comes from a comprehensive dataset of roads by type, quality and surface in Nepal as of 2015, gathered from DOLIDAR and the Department of Roads. Includes SRN, DRCN, SUN and VRCN road types. This dataset was collected district-by-district from district governments for the World Bank's Rural Access Index project.

fields.abstract: This dataset shows the estimated number of pregnancies across Nepal for 2015, aggregated by municipality. All numbers, including past and present numbers, are estimations. These estimations are created through a mix of remotely sensed (satellite) data, inputs from the Ministry of Health and inputs from the UN population division (UNFPA).
fields.source: This data was produced by the WorldPop program (www.worldpop.org) at the University of Southampton . Please note the data is a rough, estimate and errors or inconsistencies in some areas are to be expected.

fields.abstract:
This dataset shows the estimated number of live births across Nepal for 2015, aggregated by municipality. All numbers, including past and present numbers, are estimations. These estimations are created through a mix of remotely sensed (satellite) data, inputs from the Ministry of Health and inputs from the UN Population Division.

We have calculated the range for each municipality.
 
.
fields.source: This data was produced by the WorldPop program (www.worldpop.org) at the University of Southampton . Please note the data is a rough, estimate and errors or inconsistencies in some areas are to be expected.

fields.abstract:
This dataset shows the estimated number of live births across Nepal for 2015, aggregated by municipality. All numbers, including past and present numbers, are estimations. These estimations are created through a mix of remotely sensed (satellite) data, inputs from the Ministry of Health and inputs from the UN Population Division.

We have calculated  variance for each municipality.
fields.source: This data was produced by the WorldPop program (www.worldpop.org) at the University of Southampton . Please note the data is a rough, estimate and errors or inconsistencies in some areas are to be expected.

fields.full_title: Travel Times to Medical Facilities, Monsoon Season
fields.abstract: Average travel times to the nearest medical facility, calculated in hours, for monsoon season travel. This is calculated via a model of on-road and off-road travel speeds, modified by landcover, slope, altitude, road conditions and the season (monsoon or not).
fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.full_title: Travel Times to Hospitals, Monsoon Season
fields.abstract: Average travel times to the hospital, calculated in hours, for monsoon season travel. This is calculated via a model of on-road and off-road travel speeds, modified by landcover, slope, altitude, road conditions and the season (monsoon or not).
fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.full_title: Travel Times to Banks, Monsoon Season
fields.abstract: Average travel times to the nearest banks, calculated in hours, for monsoon season travel. This is calculated via a model of on-road and off-road travel speeds, modified by landcover, slope, altitude, road conditions and the season (monsoon or not).
fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.full_title: Travel Times to District Headquarters, Monsoon Season
fields.abstract: Average travel times to the nearest former district headquarters, calculated in hours, for monsoon season travel. This is calculated via a model of on-road and off-road travel speeds, modified by landcover, slope, altitude, road conditions and the season (monsoon or not).
fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.full_title: Travel Times to Financial Institutions, Monsoon Season
fields.abstract: Average travel times to the nearest financial institutions, calculated in hours, for monsoon season travel. This is calculated via a model of on-road and off-road travel speeds, modified by landcover, slope, altitude, road conditions and the season (monsoon or not).
fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.full_title: Travel Times to Public Hospitals, Monsoon Season
fields.abstract: Average travel times to the nearest public hospital, calculated in hours, for monsoon season travel. This is calculated via a model of on-road and off-road travel speeds, modified by landcover, slope, altitude, road conditions and the season (monsoon or not).

fields.full_title: Travel Times to Health Posts, Monsoon Season
fields.abstract: Average travel times to the nearest health post or sub-health post, calculated in hours, for monsoon season travel. This is calculated via a model of on-road and off-road travel speeds, modified by landcover, slope, altitude, road conditions and the season (monsoon or not).
fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.full_title: Travel Times to Major Markets (Towns), Monsoon Season
fields.abstract: Average travel times to the  nearest large market, here defined as a major town, calculated in hours, for monsoon season travel. This is calculated via a model of on-road and off-road travel speeds, modified by landcover, slope, altitude, road conditions and the season (monsoon or not).
fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.full_title: Travel Times to Private Hospitals, Monsoon Season
fields.abstract: Average travel times to the nearest private hospital, calculated in hours, for monsoon season travel. This is calculated via a model of on-road and off-road travel speeds, modified by landcover, slope, altitude, road conditions and the season (monsoon or not).
fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.full_title: Travel Times to Financial Institutions, Monsoon Season (Walking)
fields.abstract: Average travel times to the nearest financial institutions (walking), calculated in hours, for monsoon season travel. This is calculated via a model of on-road and off-road travel speeds, modified by landcover, slope, altitude, road conditions and the season (monsoon or not).
fields.source: Banick and Kawasoe (2019) “Measuring Inequality of Access: Modeling Physical Remoteness in Nepal” World Bank Policy Research Paper forthcoming

fields.abstract: The number of formal (Class A-D) financial institutions in each municipality. This dataset was collected in 2016-2017 by the Nepal Rastra Bank (NRB) with the support of the UN Capital Development Fund (UNCDF).

fields.source: Drawn from a dataset of all the health facilities in Nepal collected by the Ministry of Health in 2016.

fields.abstract: This dataset shows the estimated population density (per square kilometer) for each municipality for 2010. All numbers, including past and present numbers, are estimations. These estimations are created through a mix of census data, population growth projections, mobile phone call records, remotely sensed (satellite) data, and estimates from the UN Population Division.
fields.source: The WorldPop program (www.worldpop.org) at the University of Southampton

fields.abstract:
This dataset shows the estimated number of pregnancies across Nepal, aggregated by municipality. All numbers, including past and present numbers, are estimations. These estimations are created through a mix of remotely sensed (satellite) data, inputs from the Ministry of Health and inputs from the UN population division (UNFPA). 

We have calculated the mean for each municipality.
fields.source: The WorldPop program (www.worldpop.org) at the University of Southampton

fields.abstract:
This dataset shows the estimated number of pregnancies across Nepal, aggregated by municipality. All numbers, including past and present numbers, are estimations. These estimations are created through a mix of remotely sensed (satellite) data, inputs from the Ministry of Health and inputs from the UN population division (UNFPA). 

We have calculated the  range for each municipality.
fields.source: The WorldPop program (www.worldpop.org) at the University of Southampton

fields.abstract:
This dataset shows the estimated number of pregnancies across Nepal, aggregated by municipality. All numbers, including past and present numbers, are estimations. These estimations are created through a mix of remotely sensed (satellite) data, inputs from the Ministry of Health and inputs from the UN population division (UNFPA). 

We have calculated the  variance for each municipality.
fields.source: The WorldPop program (www.worldpop.org) at the University of Southampton

fields.abstract: The total length of rivers and major streams below 3500. A covariate for ease of economic development, as fast-moving rivers can block easy movement and transportation of goods. Rivers above 3500m are assumed to be slower moving and easier to cross on foot.
fields.source: All data derived from OpenStreetMap in April 2019

fields.source: Generated by ICIMOD from analysis of satellite imagery.

fields.source: Generated by ICIMOD from analysis of satellite imagery.

fields.abstract: The International Wealth Index (IWI) for Nepal in 2006. The IWI is an internationally standardized wealth index which calculates wealth in terms of assets based on household surveys. This model extrapolated survey results in Nepal to non-surveyed areas based on phone records and top-up patterns, night lights, census data and other factors which were shown to have a proven relationship to observed household charactersitics in the available survey data. The mean  is calculated for this index and the interdecile range (a measure of uncertainty).
fields.source: Basco, Garavito, Rigo, Tatem , Pezzulo, Wood, Chamberlain, and Bird (2018) "Geostatistical Tools to Map the Interaction between Development Aid and Indices of Need"
